description: {"blocks":[{"key":"81hpm","text":"We here provide a protocol for the decontamination of ancient bones and teeth that is based on a temperature-controlled, sequential release of DNA. DNA can be extracted from all fractions generated with this method and the fraction with the highest proportion of endogenous DNA identified for further analysis. The protocol proceeds through repeated incubation of the sample powder in phosphate buffer at 37, 60 and 90 °C, followed by the complete lysis of the residual sample powder. As DNA is denatured at high temperature, subsequent DNA extraction and library preparation has to be performed using methods optimized for single-stranded DNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"68fi4","text":"If desired, DNA extraction can also be performed on the Tris-Tween buffer, but DNA yields are expected to be extremely low.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: DNA purification of phosphate fractions and final lysate
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"42bai","text":"For the sodium phosphate fractions, purify 100 µl of the supernatant, and for the final lysate, purify 500 µl using binding buffer ‘G’ of the DNA extraction method described in Glocke and Meyer (2017). Final volume of all DNA extracts is 50 µl.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ct6ca","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"276lg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Glocke I, Meyer M","can_edit":1,"date":"1498867200","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1101/gr.219675.116","guid":"496067F6341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Genome research","protocol_id":"0","title":"Extending the spectrum of DNA sequences retrieved from ancient bones and teeth."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dohf6","text":"Prepare DNA libraries using 20% of the DNA extract as input, following the protocol for library preparation, quantification and indexing by Gansauge et al. (2020). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"30h1c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"arav9","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4ocl8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dpqr","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Gansauge MT, Aximu-Petri A, Nagel S, Meyer M","can_edit":1,"date":"1596240000","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1038/s41596-020-0338-0","guid":"4960683B341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Nature protocols","protocol_id":"0","title":"Manual and automated preparation of single-stranded DNA libraries for the sequencing of DNA from ancient biological remains and other sources of highly degraded DNA."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4ul1v","text":"Perform shallow shotgun sequencing on Illumina’s MiSeq or HiSeq2500 platforms (or other Illumina platforms) using a paired-end double-index configuration (2x 76 + 2x 7 cycles). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3rsog","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"b8641","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fvhka","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Kircher M, Sawyer S, Meyer M","can_edit":1,"date":"1325376000","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gkr771","guid":"49606880341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Nucleic acids research","protocol_id":"0","title":"Double indexing overcomes inaccuracies in multiplex sequencing on the Illumina platform."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"admji","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"98dbq","text":"Trim adapters and merge overlapping paired-end reads into single-molecule sequences using leeHom. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"75bc1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"d49vh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Renaud G, Stenzel U, Kelso J","can_edit":1,"date":"1412121600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gku699","guid":"496068C5341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Nucleic acids research","protocol_id":"0","title":"leeHom: adaptor trimming and merging for Illumina sequencing reads."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fogd8","text":"Use the Burrows-Wheeler Aligner  (BWA, https://github.com/mpieva/network-aware-bwa) to align merged sequences to a suitable reference genome (e.g. turTru1.75, bosTauUMD3.1, loxAfr4) using ancient parameters (“-n 0.01 –o 2 –l 16500”) allowing more mismatches and indels.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a8paj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fa6i5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5f0j5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1vpdl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Li H, Durbin R","can_edit":1,"date":"1267401600","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btp698","guid":"49606B05341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Bioinformatics (Oxford, England)","protocol_id":"0","title":"Fast and accurate long-read alignment with Burrows-Wheeler transform."}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"","data":{"authors":"Meyer M, Kircher M, Gansauge MT, Li H, Racimo F, Mallick S, Schraiber JG, Jay F, Prüfer K, de Filippo C, Sudmant PH, Alkan C, Fu Q, Do R, Rohland N, Tandon A, Siebauer M, Green RE, Bryc K, Briggs AW, Stenzel U, Dabney J, Shendure J, Kitzman J, Hammer MF, Shunkov MV, Derevianko AP, Patterson N, Andrés AM, Eichler EE, Slatkin M, Reich D, Kelso J, Pääbo S","can_edit":1,"date":"1350000000","doi":"https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1224344","guid":"49606A98341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","journal":"Science (New York, N.Y.)","protocol_id":"0","title":"A high-coverage genome sequence from an archaic Denisovan individual."}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4hgmm","text":"Restrict further analyses to sequences of length 35 bp and above to avoid spurious alignments of short sequences with random similarity to the reference genome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bt5sq","text":"Merge sequences with the same start- and end-coordinate into one consensus sequence using bam-rmdup (https://github.com/mpieva/biohazard-tools).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":101,"length":41}],"data":[]},{"key":"ai4ii","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"D1ACC45FA36411EBA7270A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/mpieva/biohazard-tools"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"emkvc","text":"Generate summary statistics using samtools and choose the library with the highest proportion of endogenous DNA for further sequencing.
